pros: Pretty decent benefits: vacation, sick and holidays. Good insurance. Tuition remission.
cons: The pay is horrible. Not competitive at all. They try to use their brand and benefits to compensate for the below market salary offers. The administration works their staff to the bone and you can visibly see the burnout. Worst part is the bigotry and cronyism that runs rampant without any accountability. Documented incidents are ignored. Staff across campus are there one day, speak up or report discrimination, and quietly gone the next time you look for them. Admissions staff of Color leaving in droves, Student Life sweeping reports of misogyny under the rug to keep business moving. Student services staff stretched thin. Faculty abusive to staff. DEI workshops/meetings/guest lectures and “community dialogues” are for show. Reports to OEO are “inconclusive” and staff are gaslit. Toxic place to work. Not worth the brand recognition. Go work at another institution where you actually get paid somewhat closer to a livable wage, and HR holds their racist/misogynistic/ staff  and faculty accountable.

job_title: Dental School Employee in Boston, MA
pros: Great Benefits Package, Working with Residents and Students in a learning environment rewarding, co workers are amazing people
cons:
Work/ life balance does not exist due to lack of staff, executive management teams makes uniformed decisions without understanding the day to day operations of other departments. 
HR team is horrific, hiring new employees takes months for stupid reasons. Absolutely no common sense. HR issues regarding certain employees discussed numerous times but employees seem protected, while others that executive management team have personality differences with are let go or stifled for no reason. Although it is communicated that there is a no retaliation policy if you approach HR regarding issues you get labelled as the difficult one and are very much targeted.
More and more work gets piled on current employees with absolutely no additional compensation or appreciation.
A cut throat atmosphere has been created by certain teams (Finance and billing). The Director of Clinical Finance constantly seems to seek to destroy morale of the school rather than implementing course of actions through collaboration and constructive communication. Many of the recent departures are due to this inept executive management, which was my reason for leaving the company.

pros: Benefits are great: health insurance, time off, sick time, 12 weeks paid family leave, plus insurance for car & home offered with MetLife. Tuition reimbursement.  There are other great benefits which I don't use.
cons:
Health insurance is very expensive! Also pay is low and in my department the wage gap between women and men is evident.  Little opportunity for advancement after starting in supervisory role 6 years ago.  Politics and bureaucracy is a bit sickening - the Medford campus is the worst.  All 4 campuses don't work well together and they all want to do their own thing.  

I've have several different bosses all men- and despite reporting verbal and non-verbal sexual harassment HR does nothing about it.  

Medford campus wants salaried employees to work 7 days straight at certain times of the year but stopped offering comp time there forcing us to use earned vacation time for days off after working non-stop.  Our department expects everyone to work at least 40hrs/week.  Certain managers demand a lot more.

review_title: Caught in the middle of a transition
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Medford, MA
pros:
-Worked at student tech services during a part of my enrollment at Tufts. 
-Worked with two great managers who really trusted in their staff and made their student workers and fellow staff members feel valued.
-Work environment was loose, informal, and almost like a surrogate family, surrounded by great people and steadfast and receptive leadership.
-Given ability to collaborate, grow, and learn from full time staff members within the department.
cons:
-Both managers left, each giving over 10 years of service to the university.
-Management put in a new, green manager who didn't know the operations of student tech services.
-Manager proceeded to create policies and procedures that was detrimental to students, favorited certain people and targeted others, was not responsive to feedback from students, and made the workplace a much more tense and unwelcoming place.
-New manager forced out talented students and co-ops who they didn't personally want to stay, and severely handicapped other workers who are still there today.
-Absolutely no room for advancement, be it horizontal or vertical.
-Constant theme that student supervisors knew more than the new manager.

pros:
Free classes at a top tier university. If you can put in the time, you can earn a Master's for free. There's also a reimbursement program if you want to take classes somewhere other than Tufts. 

Great place to start your career.
cons:
The pay is low, and there are few opportunities for advancement. You really have to fight hard to get a promotion or a raise. 

Tufts in general is also struggling financially - budget deficits across the board. A large part of this is the administrative bloat, and a lack of thriftiness on the part of budget decision makers. Some of that is unavoidable in an institution of this size, but improving coordination across departments would increase efficiency and help a lot with that. 

I've seen events that are very similar booked at the same time, in the same building. I've also heard rumors of paying multiple thousands of dollars for an outside speaker to come talk for 90 minutes on diversity & inclusion, instead of having someone come from the Equal Opportunity office right across campus.

job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Medford, MA
pros: If not working for TTS, it should be good. If working within TTS, it depends on the individual manager. Be sure to gossip around to find out if the manager you would report to is good or not. One huge benefit: Employee Tuition Remission. Get your degree, for free, while being paid to work. Also the retirement benefit is incredibly good.
cons: Depending on which dept / manager, there are a lot of areas of dysfunctionality and toxic environment, where managers yell or smash things. Not all areas are bad. Just make sure you know about your specific manager, through friends or connections, before joining.

review_title: Benefits Great, Climate Needs Some Work
pros: Vacation, sick, retirement and health benefits are all pretty top-notch.  Campus is environmentally conscious.  Pretty well-resourced.  Lots of attention to system and infrastructure improvement.
cons:
Salaries are OK, but merit increases barely track with cost of living increases. Make sure you push for as high a starting salary as possible, it won't move upward very fast unless you change your actual job description which is hard.

Worst part of campus is climate that doesn't seem to get the importance of open and honest dialogue and a less than inclusive way of operating.  Pretty corporate, command / control model.  Administration way of dealing with student dissent is pretty authoritarian rather than learning and development oriented.

review_title: Does not value staff of color and no room for growth
pros: - Benefits, but that's about it
cons:
- Very low pay and even lower raises. Pay levels inconsistent to the cost of living, especially in Medford/Somerville and even Downtown Boston areas. 
- Overworks their underpaid staff and spreads them thin. 
- Unfriendly work environment. Hostile to people of color, especially queer trans people of color. 
- No room for advancement or growth. They keep saying the deficit impedes them from allowing staff to at least attend  conferences 
- No sense of community amongst staff. Too much hierarchy. 
- There is no staff outing to foster a supportive environment
- Higher ranks in administration make too many important decisions that greatly impact the community but does not care to consult the community
- Touts their diversity on the school pamphlet and website but does nothing to support staff, faculty, and students of color

review_title: Tufts is a good place to be an engineering grad student
pros: as an engineering grad student with a sponsored research project, i was made to feel like a valuable member of the team. my advisors allowed me to participate in all decisions involving my research. all the advantages of being on a college campus also applied.
cons: as a grad student, you will not be paid well and, in my case anyway, my advisors tended to lose sight of the fact that low pay and an expensive area to live can be trying.  the student health insurance is poor.  you have no defined vacation or sick days. you will be given all sorts of crappy little jobs at the last second - "the deadline for submitting a paper is this afternoon! drop everything you're doing and take care of it!"

pros: I was in the Microbiology dept at Tufts Medical as a post doc. The dept is friendly and helpful. Interactions are easy and all are easy to approach. If you want to learn a new technique, use some equipment  you just need to ask around.
cons: Very low post doc salary. Despite having two years of prior post doc experience I was counted as a new post doc and started at the lowest wage. The post doc lasted through the economic downturn and raises were minimal even though I asked if something could be done. Departmental administration team is the best. They did the best they could to see if they could get me a better salary but all raises at the time were prohibited. As a post doc, be aware of what you should be making and if you aren't, do something.

review_title: Casual and easy to hold down job for full-time Tufts students
job_title: Circulation Desk Student Assistant, Tisch Library in Medford, MA
pros: A relatively easily obtainable and flexible job for Tufts students looking to work part-time during the school year, especially for those who don't have work study. The job doesn't require much in terms of responsibilities, and often you can just spend an entire shift reading or studying at the desk while occasionally checking out books and answering questions.
cons: Pay isn't great (they usually keep it just above MA minimum wage), and sometimes you're asked to constantly perform tasks throughout a shift like searching for books in the stacks, shelving books, or fixing printers (and there's never any training for that)--really just depends on when the shift is and who the supervisor is. Some supervisors can be difficult to work with, but mostly they range from fine to very chill and understanding.

review_title: Great place to learn many aspects of life
pros: Learning and doing research here was truly helpful and a great preparation for subsequent jobs. Though there might not have been an abundance of money as compared to other big universities in the area, I feel the experience was in that sense closer to real life challenges. Comparing the work ethic of students at different universities I can honestly say that the average Tufts student has an above average drive to do the job right. Most importantly I believe Tufts instills a very pleasant work environment.
cons: Unfortunately the infrastructure varied greatly between departments. In some places facilities were leaking and falling apart and other places the buildings were brand new and state of the art. The Medford campus is a little bit removed from the hotspots in Boston.

pros: Tufts is a relatively relaxed environment. It's possible to maintain (in theory) a good work/life balance. Some of the faculty here are interesting. There's a discount available on courses, if your manager will authorize them. May be a good "pre retirement" move when you're ready to slow down.
cons: Tufts is not a place to go if you're looking to further your career. It's a bit of where innovation goes to die. As a staffer coming from the private sector, I was arguably unprepared for the lack of professionalism, motivation, and engaged colleagues. Instead, it was slow moving, bureaucratic, inefficient, and bogged down by political infighting. Best summed up by a departmental leader who was describing not doing her work and said "The faculty here are tenured. It's the same for staff. They aren't going to fire you."

review_title: Review for Department of Physics and Astronomy
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Medford, MA
pros:
Grants: Graduate students becoming research assistant usually after first year. (Depends on the field, experimental areas in good shape)
If you need to travel due to your research you are paid extra, most of the universities does not do this.
Small but specialized faculty
Management is concerned with graduate student needs, it is very easy to contact with them. They act quickly to solve the problem
cons:
Small Department
Not much different research options, it is good only if you are interested in a specific area
Offered courses are limited.  Most of the students need to wait until a new elective course to be offered to finish course work

review_title: Overall great place to work with friendly people and great benefits.
pros: Your experience at Tufts will depend on the department, but I found my fellow staffers to be generally kind and supportive.  Great benefits and pay helped when to compensate for the little annoyances when things get hectic.
cons: Some of the technology they use is pretty out-dated, but I believe they are trying to upgrade soon.  It is also impossible, as far as I know, to switch career tracks (i.e., from administrative to teaching or something).  Communications between departments can sometimes be a bit tense, depending on the department.

review_title: Good postdoc experience at Tufts University school of medicine
pros: Work environment is very supportive and friendly.  Available equipment covers almost all needs.  Sharing and collaboration among labs is a huge plus.  Location in chinatown in Boston means you're 5 min walk away from most subway lines (green, orange, red) and 8-10 min walk away from south station for commuter rail.
cons: Boston campus does not have a respectable gym for employees and postdocs.  Year to year salary increase has been less than inflation rate for the past three years.  Teaching opportunity is scarce since Boston campus does not have undergraduate departments.  Commuting by car would  be a big mistake because of location, though that will not be a problem for most people (see pros)

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Associate in Boston, MA
pros: People is very nice and friendly, easy to collaborate. Tufts is starting to implement the 5 years postdocs rule, after that you must be upgrade to research associate otherwise you leave. The department Manager is really outstanding, proactive and very professional. He has been very helpful troubleshooting postdocs issues.
cons: International Office and Human resources are unreliable and mediocre. I was working in Ivy league university previously and Tufts management of visa renewals is poorly organized. Many postdocs having issues with Taxes devolution since HR/IO lack of knowledge of how international tax treatments work. Health coverage is ok but get really expensive with dependents. Salaries are low, only minimum NIH and is very hard to get increases so better negotiate a good entry salary before to start

pros:
I served as both RA and TA during my grad school. 
Serving as TA is a very unique experience, you will be involved in helping students on projects during the office hours. It can help you improve your own skill set. And provide you a good insight into teaching (if you are interested), also you can build good relations with professors.
While doing all that you can get your grad research done as RA and take courses of your choice.
cons: You will not earn same money as you can in industry, but it's till good enough to help you live a comfortable life.

pros: The multidisciplinary work environment at Tufts allows the employees to have a well-rounded experience.  Upper level management are very accessible and willing to help new and young employees develop their careers.
cons: As a small Tier I research institution, the facilities and resources can leave something to be desired compared to many of the much larger technical institutes.  In general, working in academia is not as lucrative as pursing industry as an engineer.

review_title: Poor management and unvalue on people
pros: Generous vacation time, great benefit, convenient location
cons: Management is only pleasing the PIs, and not valuing on the administration staff. Turnover rate is extremely high, average 1+ year including the people pursuing graduate degrees for free. Hiring process is very slow.  There is no appropriate training and you need to figure out your own. Entire Tufts University is trying to centralize the administration, but the structure is a disaster that makes a simple task to complete ridiculously long. Very labor intense and lack of infrastructure investment. To gain some experiences for graduate students or postdocs, Tufts University in Boston is very good place, or is great place only as a stepping stone to advance your career to next level.

review_title: A strong sense of community, great work-life balance
job_title: Special Projects Manager in Medford, MA
pros:
Great colleagues who love what they do
Great students
A strong feeling of community
Generous time-off policy, generous support for continuing education
Great work-life balance
Access to the gym, a great library
My office (a subdivision of Tufts) has a great leadership team
cons:
Very few opportunities for growth
Recently instituted shared services are a mess, providing terrible quality of service
A very resource-constrained environment
Very siloed

pros:
- Benefits are good, but not competitive in the market in comparison to research institutions/collaborations in area
- Beautiful campus (Medford/Somerville)
cons:
- Upper management is rather disconnected from rest of staff
- Reorg of administration focused too low, need to take a look in the mirror
- Centralization of major administrative functions (Payroll/Accts Payable/Purchasing/etc) has not gone well and no one is willing to admit it or try to fix.

review_title: Great place to work as a student
pros: Lots of student jobs that allow you to study. Supervisors very relaxed and flexible about schedules. They are also very fair about pay grades and increases. I found out from my supervisor that every year they discuss what students do at the job, and then discuss how much they should be compensated. My last year everyone got a pay raise because they felt we did more than the job was paying us too. Also, we got regular incremental raises for length of time employed.
cons: Some jobs pay better than others. I would look around at my options before committing to one particular job.

pros: Tufts University is a place where a lot of interesting things happen.  They offer job security and one of the best benefit and vacation packages in the market.
cons: There are large problems with management. Almost no one is willing to take a responsible decision when people are not productive.  There is also a cast system, were faculty can get away with anything.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Medford, MA
pros:
I worked as a graduate teaching assistant at Tufts for 3 semesters. 
My normal hours included time spent in class, weekly office hours, and recitations. 
On top of that, I spent between 20-30 hours a week on grading.
cons:
As our department did not have many teaching assistants, the workload was immense. 
TA'ing for the larger freshman-level lecture courses was especially taxing. 
The professor also allowed nearly unlimited time for exams, meaning exam proctors could sometimes have to stay on campus until after midnight.

pros:
It's a university, so you get a lot of great benefits, including tuition remission.  Most departments will keep you happy for a few years.  Parking costs are not as high as BU or Harvard.  In terms of weather, we pretty much only close if the Governor says we should.  (MIT is similar).  Some depts are great with flexibility.  My boss is great with a new mother and a mother of two young girls.  It's definitely worth getting into for ~3 years.  You get a 401(a) that they contribute to.  (You don't have to match!!)  You get to keep it if you put in 3 years.

Great way to get experience and get out of Tufts.
cons:
Tufts is totally disorganized and does not care about department administrations.   If you work in central, there may be less BS, but if you work in a dept, you are valued little.  A LOT of turnover to Harvard, where people are paid more for the same type of work.  We joke that we are a feeder school to Harvard for STAFF.  Ridiculously high turnover.

You have to put up with a lot of guesswork.  Not much information from Central admin.  I often get information from other universities in regard to federal regulations (related to my job).

HR is absolutely awful.  I handle payroll in my (large) dept, and I can tell you those people don't care about doing anything on a timely basis.  If you are looking at becoming a postdoc, plan on them losing your paperwork.  Really.  I'm sorry.

review_title: Hard to get a job if you aren't work-study
pros: if you lived on campus they worked well with your schedule.  further if you have work study its easy to get a job.  just go to jobx.
cons: It was extremely hard to get a job as a student without workstudy.  I found only a few jobs that would even hire me unless you want to work in the dining hall. one was lifeguarding because of my license and DevTech in the CD department.

pros:
Amazing benefits and healthy work/life balance
Parking prices are very reasonable, ample parking and the parking office is really nice and easy going
Can take classes for free!
Beautiful campuses, very clean, well taken care of
Library is an outstanding resource, and very conducive to creating an optimal learning environment
The Faculty are professional, respectful, passionate, beyond intelligent and innovative. They really care about and take an interest in the students. 
Students are very studious, diverse and get involved in so many meaningful activities in addition to taking classes full time, and working and traveling.
Multiple, wide variety or academic programs to choose from including undergraduate and graduate degrees.
Plenty of opportunity to get involved and be part of something bigger and better then yourself
Researchers are doing top-notch, ground breaking, life changing work
Excellent Tufts Police force, very responsive and caring about your safety, wellness and well being
Tufts Events are always superior and they have the best guest special event guest speakers
Lots of opportunities to engage with Senior Management
Managers invest in their employees and there are plenty of training and professional development opportunities
Lots of positive financial investment in newer Academic buildings and redesigning more Academic buildings.
cons:
Food prices in cafeterias are okay for the type of food that is served. Don't get me wrong the food is actually pretty tasty, just not as reasonable cost wise as you may expect.
Tufts Shuttle is sometimes unreliable and Tufts is not directly subway accessible (but it is bus accessible), but it will be subway accessible if the MBTA extends the green line. 
Annual Raises are not that significant, but at least you reliably get one every year
Salaries are generally not competitive for similar industry jobs, but employee benefits are more than competitive
Campus is very hilly, bring your walking shoes. It can be difficult to drive/walk around at times in the winter, even though facilities does a great job clearing snow and keeping the campus safe

review_title: Tufts Medical School is a great place to work in biomedical research.
pros: I work at the Medical School doing research.  The working environment is excellent, the labs are well maintained and have new adequate equipment, and the majority of the faculty/students are a pleasure to work with.  The close proximity to Chinatown is a great bonus.
cons: Some of the departments could be administered better, but your working experience is mostly influence by your direct boss - so make sure you have a good relationship and are interested in the research.

review_title: Tufts Classics Office: Very Solid Part Time Job For Students
job_title: Office Assistant in Tufts University, MA
pros: I was an Office Assistant in the Tufts University Classics Office. The administrative assistant who I reported to was extremely friendly and a pleasure to work with. It was a good way to interact with professors, and I was able to rearrange my schedule when needed.
cons: This was exactly what it sounds like: You're doing administrative backup for an academic institution part-time. It is not likely to be the most exciting position of your career. But of any of the part time jobs I could have had on campus, this was a great choice.

review_title: Eight years at Tufts in a managerial role
pros: Small enough to have a community feel; beautiful slightly suburban campus; good benefits; great students
cons: Small size means limited opportunities for advancement in specific roles (it is the nature of higher ed that people stay in management roles for a long time) so with a smaller school, it is natural that there would be fewer openings.  It is not Tufts' fault, it is just the nature of the beast.  Good people have left, not because they didn't like Tufts, but pursued more senior roles at larger universities in the area.

review_title: Stable job with solid benefits and great coworkers
pros:
-Great health insurance, generous sick policy, and on-site nurses just for employees; they really have your back when it comes to health
-Full-time employees can take classes at the university (amazing)
-Very steady 9-5 lifestyle (or 8-4 or 10-6 depending on what you worked out with your supervisor, outside of the parental flex time options)
-Flexible scheduling options for parents
-On-site gym, pool, library
-Solid vacation policy
-Great coworkers; lots of nice, friendly, helpful people around
-Anyone is willing to talk to you about what they do, if you're exploring career paths
-They automatically put an amount equal to 5% of your salary into a retirement account, whether or not you're also contributing (unlike a matching program). Vests after 3 years. This is an awesome benefit.
-Pretty easy to bike or bus from surrounding areas.
-Overall, it's easy to have a great lifestyle at Tufts. Having moved into a more lucrative / more demanding / less lifestyle-friendly industry, this is an important benefit. 
-You can build a career here, if that's what you want. Lots of folks stay a very long time.
cons:
-Very slow advancement/promotion cycle, which I think is typical for the industry but still a bummer
-Stagnation. While 9-5 is great for having a life outside of work, it's very easy to coast, not work with urgency, or stop improving your skillset. Great for parents or folks who are settled in their careers, not as great for people who want to grow their careers and be challenged. That said, you can learn a lot by pushing yourself. There are opportunities to learn and grow.
-Bad employees stick around. Nice to know your job is safe, not nice to work with a slacker. 
-Pay is typically below  industry standards.
-Within University Advancement, there can be a bit of a divide between development officers and everybody else. When I was there, leadership mostly consisted of development officers, many of whom were absolutely brilliant DOs and mediocre business leaders. (Lots of smart, personable, skilled fundraisers with seemingly little appreciation for other parts of the org. Made me appreciate the value of a business degree. ) Overall, it often felt as though DOs' needs/preferences came before other departments'.

pros: Once you are hired, it is a nice community in which to work.  It offers good benefits.
cons: There have been some organizational changes at Tufts in the last three years and it is not as customer service friendly to its employees.  I plan to leave as soon as I find another job.

review_title: Poor choice administrative changes with new regime, lowers staff growth and loss of jobs.
pros: Great dental plan, wonderful coworkers, good employee tuition remission program, average vacation policy, good sick time policy.
cons: Constant hushed layoffs, new call centers reduce work efficiency, expensive and limited health insurance, no growth, too political, children go for free as long as they meet all the culturally diverse "requirements", limited parking, terrible work/life balance for staff, pay does not keep up with cost of living...most staff make <50k ...

pros:
> Amazing sick leave policy and decent vacation policy
> Pays for 1 class a semester to take for credit (you will pay taxes if it doesn't relate to your job)
> Relaxed atmosphere (mostly)
> Good health insurance and nice perks for being staff (full gym access, etc.)
cons:
> Idiosyncratic bureaucracy
> Little promotional potential
> Deadly quiet in summer but required to stay (you do get paid for it)

review_title: a plus or two for grad students
pros:
The graduate students here come from a lot of backgrounds.  You don't see a single mold for how to come here and succeed.  There are lots of older students with backgrounds to bring with them and even children.

Also, I feel the quality of the work I'm able to do from here is very high.
cons: Grad student life for PhDs is probably not going to be great in most places.  I also suppose it depends a lot on the department.  In mine, I get the distinct attitude of disdain toward us.

review_title: I was an undergraduate research assistant in two labs at Tufts.
pros: Some professors are great; students are cool people; lots of flexibility in your hours.  In one lab in particular, I worked with a bunch of undergraduates and grad students, and we all got along very well.
cons: Some professors are hard to reach or non-responsive, but that

review_title: Good experience to perform innovative cutting edge research
pros: Have many resources at your disposal to conduct research.  Top notch principal investigators.  There is an open atmosphere to engage in collaborations with other labs.
cons: Not the best advocacy for post-doctoral scholars.  Low stipend and benefits.  Not the best communication to post docs of the seminars and grand rounds given at the medical center.  Not much interplay between the basic scientists and clinicians.

pros: As a grad student in the CS department, some of the professors are amazing, they really care about their students and devote a lot of time and attention to them.
cons: There are one or two professors who make life difficult for everyone else without contributing a  whole lot themselves. Although they might think they do. Also, the quals process is much more involved in the CS department than other universities, which puts a lot of strain on students for that semester.

review_title: Great university with good benefits, but non-competitive salary
pros:
-Good benefits including vacation, personal days, etc
-Free Tufts undergrad or grad level courses
cons:
-Salary is not competitive with other similar positions in Boston
-3 month grace period for vacation, personal days, and courses is non-negotiable

pros: Great work environment: supportive and caring, but provides a rigorous education.  Strong academic focus, with only some programs preparing students for non-academic careers
cons: Scientific funding as a whole is down-this is not Tufts fault.  But the school has several prominent and successful PIs so that every student will have proper funding.  As I mentioned above, many of the stronger programs still have a very academic focus, which is great if you want to stay in academia after your PhD; less so if you want to explore the "alternative careers."

pros: Tufts offers a pleasant working environment and exposure to faculty and students is both challenging and interesting.
cons: The managers are competent people but don't know how to deal with their employees and are poor at dealing with conflict.  Despite an employee recognition program, most staff do not feel appreciated.

review_title: Great university, but no opportunities for growth
pros: Great benefits and you can't beat the opportunity to take classes for free.
cons: There aren't any opportunities for growth and management overloads employees to the point of exhaustion at times. I can't speak on the entire University, but within my department, there is a reluctance to promote even the exemplary employees, and the employees end up leaving for other companies where they are appreciated and paid more.

review_title: Nice people, but it's a stale environment
pros: Nice people to work with, good work-life balance
cons: People openly admitted that they started working for Tufts  as their last stop before retirement. Filled with people who don't care anymore and are done trying, which means nothing is done efficiently or done well. Ended up being a frustrating place to work. And despite people saying the benefits are great, I left Tufts for a job that paid nearly 40% more with less expensive benefits.

pros: 401(a); three weeks of vacation; 35-hour work week; use of the library, gym, lectures, etc.; tuition remission; relatively laidback work environment; wellness center
cons: Bureaucracy, lack of communication between departments, outdated technology, HR is clueless, Tufts Support Services (centralized HR and finance center) is difficult to use

pros: Great first job, lots of great co-workers, busy work environment, and plenty of opportunities.
cons: depending on your work position, not much room for growth, unless you move departments or go outside of Tufts. Not easy to cross-train across a different discipline and HR could do a better job of  embracing what employees need.

review_title: Great for training, okay for research
pros: Tufts provides a great environment for you scientists in training. For those who are ambitious, you will easily stand out, but for those who need more training, be prepared for a long haul.
cons: Lack of imagination and creativity prevents scientists in training from honing their scientific curiosity.

review_title: Tufts IT: Where motivation goes to die
pros: Decent benefits, especially time off.   Tuition remission, beautiful campus, relatively relaxed work environment.   Schedule flexibility.
cons:
Constant reorganization with lots of middle managers shuffling around.
Complete dysfunction in many areas of central IT - management drove most of the competent employees away
No opportunity for advancement
Bureaucracy to rival the federal government
Pay is weak

review_title: Microbiology Dept at the Boston Campus
pros: Staff are very friendly and super helpful. The work environment is mostly great, but dependent on the lab. Professors are excited about teaching and promote a collaborative environment.
cons: The location isn't great, a but shady at night. And the food options get a bit boring after a while.

job_title: Music Department Employee in Medford, MA
pros: they understand that you are a student and will allow you to take time off as needed. it's a convenient job for current students.
cons: the pay is minimum and there isn't much chance of a raise. sometimes it's hard to get hired unless you are really persistent or you have a friend who works there.

pros: Good medical/dental, on-site staff health center, can take classes at a top-notch university. Environment that values learning. Can be supportive depending on your department. Good if you've got a side gig or passion project and just need a solid 9-5 to pay the billz.
cons: Don't look at Tufts to be an innovative or creative workplace. Hard to move up. Internal systems, software, and processes often clunky/mystifying. Lack of communication across the organization.  Disregard for staff in decision making.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Medford, MA
pros: World class research, located in Boston which is a major tech center.
cons: Experiences will vary on group, but I found it difficult to steer the direction of my research, and advisers can be against letting students spend time building skills in any area outside of being directly relevant to the research.  This varies however, some advisers are more flexible in this arena.

review_title: Not sure what's happening to Tufts
pros: Great benefits.  The people in my department and school are wonderful despite lots of egos.
cons: Lots of initiatives that seem to go nowhere.  After a while you just stop paying attention, keep your head down and hope they will die on the vine.  It seems it's Central versus the schools with no clear winner but lots of losers.

pros: Excellent workplace for work-study students. There are boundless opportunities in academic departments, cafes, libraries, and various buildings for students to have a great job to earn some extra money, while still making sure that studies are the most important part of their day.
cons: Not surprisingly, pay isn't fantastic, but who would expect it to be? Started off at minimum wage ($8/hr) and after 4 years working, only finished at $8.8/hr. But, again, I didn't work to make a living, just to have some extra cash.

review_title: Tufts is not competitive but flexible
pros: flexible schedule, casual environment, some good benefits
cons: Disorganized. The vacation, paid holidays and especially salary are not on par with other area universities. Their "exempt vs non-exempt" is a joke. Not exempt employees are required to report that they only worked x hours, regardless of how many hours they actually work. Which is basically the set-up of exempt employees, however, the latter have higher salaries, more vacation and better benefits.

pros: Great opportunities for research, everyone is very supportive, lots of opportunities to learn and branch out
cons: find a position and place early because its hard to get a job in a department as a senior, administration is confusing, payment can sometimes be confusing bw depts

review_title: Good as far as academic jobs go
pros:
Good facilities, location right in Chinatown so there's interesting places to eat, good amount of social happy hours and stuff for post doc's and techs to do. Open lab environment, so labs are large rooms with several groups within, which I much prefered over having smaller rooms with one group. 

Senior people were very willing to give advice and help out
cons: Cons are really just with academic career path in general. Long hours and low pay.

review_title: Working at Tufts for less than a year now.
pros: It's nice to work here-I like the people that I work with, and I like being around smart, engaged students. Also, I live close to Tufts so the University is not bad.
cons: Don't have any complaints-I've had a good experience so far. A small one is that I wish as an employee I had a discount in the dining halls. They serve a lot of students, and I feel like that would be easy to work in.

review_title: Alumni Office is a wonderful place for student workers
pros: The people at the alumni office are fun people to spend time with. The work is pretty light, salary is average, and hours are really flexible. There are always snacks and drinks available.
cons: Work can get boring at times. But it's never too bad really. Exactly what you can expect as a student intern.

pros: you get free housing, free meals, get to stay on campus, fun to work around your peers (other college students)
cons: There has recently been a power shift, and the management still here is reeling to gain the power that was left behind.  There is a lot of inner-office unprofessional-ism, and disrespect.

review_title: Overall, it's a great environment with really interesting and fun people!
pros: People at Tufts are generally very friendly and cooperative, there is a sense of family. The campus is also very beautiful and overall it's a great place to work.
cons: You can tell that management/facilities are disorganized. There were often issues with the building I was working in (such as leaks in the roof) which took days to fix. Also, they would hire external contractors to do things the university should have people to do.

review_title: good 9-5 but easy to become complacent
pros: hour lunch, interesting people, access to a lot of extra stuff if you want to put the time in to speakers
cons: Bureaucracy, most senior administration is fantastic but if you are unfortunately enough to work under one that is not, there's little chance they are going anywhere anytime soon

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Medford, MA
pros: Tufts alumni network can provide a lot of resources after leaving school. Faculty here are always helpful and supportive, they want you to succeed.
cons: As in academia anywhere, risk of burn out is high. I also wish there were more opportunities for grad students who want to go into industry rather than academia.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar in Medford, MA
pros: It is a good private uni.
cons: Everything is very slow and mostly all supervisor have their own business and company outside of  university. You cant expect growing

review_title: Tufts is a vibrant community with a great staff, but salaries are low and growth opportunities few.
pros:
- Vibrant community
- Great students and colleagues
- Generous time-off
- Tuition remission
- Good retirement benefits
- Good work/life balance
cons:
- Slow job growth, due to the bureaucratic nature of academia and relatively low turnover
- Salaries are somewhat low compared to the private sector
- Health insurance costs
- Needs to become more of a meritocracy

review_title: Program Supervisor, Tufts MAT Program - Latin and Classical Humanities
pros: An institution highly regarded in the field of Classics, and graduating young professionals with character, vision and innovation, I found the faculty with whom I had contact to be outstanding.  The MAT program is respected for its sought after graduates.
cons: There is some construction going on in Medford close to the University which makes for some difficulty with navigation around the campus.  Public transportation is recommended.

pros:
I worked within a research group and the tasks were pretty interesting.
The salary was fair for academic standards, obviously lower than industry levels.
The work environment was relaxed and the campus is great.
I was provided two work stations, one in an office on campus and one at home.
I got to take classes during the summer semester, which actually helped me get into grad school.
cons: The technologies I worked with aren't in high demand on the job market.

review_title: Great place to work, employees are passionate about what they do
pros:
-great work/life balance
-excellent benefits (health, retirement, vacation)
-employees are very nice and helpful
-surrounded by extremely smart people on a regular basis
-people love working here and stay for a long time
cons:
-not many opportunities to bond with co-workers outside of work
-not as many opportunities for career advancement because everyone stays 
-sometimes rigid structure due to checks and balances as you move up the university system

pros:
I work in a large group with a great chance of collaborations. Full of resource. Nice boss, nice colleagues. It is nice school too with smart people.
The professor is very supportive and offers great mentorship. Therefore, great chance to get hire somewhere else after you are done with postdoc.
cons:
Sometimes I feel stressful about the amount of works
Work-life balance depends on me. So, I don't complain about it.
Postdoc is not a permanent job

pros: It has world class research, great faculty and a commitment to generating good teachers. Besides, it has awesome sights and sounds.
cons: It is not within the Boston area and that sometimes hampers productivity and / or collaborative efforts. Going downtown to get some of your work done can be a pain.

pros: I LOVED being a TA! It's a fun job with incredibly flexible hours. My department was wonderful and it reflects well on Tufts as a whole.
cons: Like any university, working with specific Professors can be difficult. Different personalities!

review_title: Great school to be an all-round researcher
pros: Chemistry department is a relatively small department with young and dynamic faculty creating an excellent environment for graduate students. Access to instrumentation is never a problem. Interaction and collaboration between labs in the department is possible.
cons: The choice for rotation between different labs before picking a research group for graduate degree is limited. The social life might take a hit as a graduate student (true for any school).

pros: Good culture, great work & life balance, work that feels meaningful, thoughtful and dedicated coworkers, ample time off
cons: projects progress slowly at times, organizational politics can often get in the way of good work, too many meetings that are not productive

review_title: Non-profit university means you can do what's right instead of what's profitable, but very very slowly.
pros:
Generous hours and leave; 35 hour weeks, 4 weeks vacation, unlimited sick time.
Stable employment.
cons: Pay is not on par with commercial industry. Consensus and group-think drive decision making. Progress on any collaborative task is incredibly slow.

review_title: One of the best on-campus jobs!
pros:
Great understanding and friendly fellow staff.
Really work with your schedule.
Staff really take interest and care about your school and overall life.
Great way to stay in the know of what's happening on campus.
cons:
If other employees don't pick up the less desirable shifts, you're stuck covering them. 
Fellow students don't take care of the building so you end up cleaning up after college students.
Weekend nights can be tough.

review_title: A great place to learn skills, and meet people in the field.
pros: Academia allows for flexible schedules. Good benefits. Employees are treated extremely well. Outings with the company or individual labs foster a positive atmosphere and build relationships.
cons: Few to speak of about Tufts itself. As with any scientific institution, there can be a language barrier between employees. It can be difficult to coordinate projects when two parties are on different pages.

pros: The location of Tufts makes it very conducive to academic collaborations, especially with the medical school. Boston is the perfect city for this!
cons: Tufts is a smaller university than some of the neighboring institutions such as Harvard, MIT, etc. This can lead to reduced access to resources.

pros: good environment to develop and many ways to enrich your knowledge, good opportunity to meet people from different countries with different backgrounds
cons: location of the dental school and too strict in certain aspects, i would suggest more flexibility in terms of new employees

job_title: Work Study Student in Medford, MA
pros: As a work-study student in the Communications Department, you can form valuable relationships with Professors outside the classroom.  Often times, there are unique opportunities that wouldn't crop up anywhere else.
cons: All things considered, the pay is pretty low.  Even though the federal government is picking up part of the tab for your paycheck, don't expect to be making much above the minimum wage.

review_title: Excellent university and positive work experience
pros: Student workers are able to easily balance academics with work, which allows them to stay on top of their schedules while making some income on the side. Compensation for many basic office administration jobs is better than one  would expect.
cons: Personal growth as an employee is better earned working for a non-academic institution. Student workers usually work to supplement their college experience.

pros: Good location in the campus and the city. Relaxed atmosphere, within and between groups. Good science is occurring. Sensible requirements for graduation.
cons: Cramp building, but they are adding a new science building. Lack of department support from faculty and the department at large.

job_title: Student Employee At Fletcher School in Medford, MA
pros: I had no problem with my boss(es) or the students I worked with, but it was a fairly cut-and-dry job of filing, copying, and coursework organization. Nothing amazing but to be expected.
cons: Dull work which could have been done by freshmen.

review_title: Needs a complete overhaul of the upper Administration
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Unethical management, no resource available to confidentially report problems with management without retaliation, under-qualified managers, jobs and pay given by association not experience or merit, inept hr services

job_title: Photo Editor/Senior Staff Photographer in Medford, MA
pros: People are nice and easy to talk to in the lab that I work at. Mostly low stake tasks when you first start, more responsibility as experience accumulates
cons: unpaid intern, not very much contact with PI, a lot of mundane data entry and processing tasks - can get very tedious

pros: Flexible schedule, coworkers were easy to get along with
cons: The whole center is under funded and it shows and trickles down to salaries. Morale is poor due to this sad reality.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Medford, MA
pros: Professors have time to mentor students and a research is encouraged. There are many on-campus resources and funding sources to support research. In addition, Tufts encourages interdisciplinary cooperation and innovative approaches to work.
cons: It is not uncommon for departments to be limited in size and expertise available but help can easily be obtained from professors in other programs within the school.

review_title: Tufts University supports employees through benefits and training.
pros: Tufts has a collaborative environment that encourages citizenship and commitment.
cons: Parking in downtown Boston is difficult and expensive.  Tufts has three very distinct campuses and public transportation between each is limited.

pros: Benefits; great peers; location; helpful staff
